title: Publicly Calling out Scripters - What's Riot's stance?
body:
It's getting to the stage where I could safely say every person who reads this has seen or at least heard of someone scripting in League of Legends. I'm just curious as to what Riot's stance is on calling out such players for their cheating ways? I'm aware with various other rules (mainly toxic players) Riot doesn't encourage publicly calling out offenders, though I was curious if this is the same for scripters. I'm mostly interested in Riot's stance on videos pointing out obvious scripters, though also interested in if calling players out in game is allowed.


**FAQ:**
**Isn't a ban enough?**: Sure, the scripters will indeed receive a ban if they're scripting, though this takes weeks (if not months) to actually be put into action. Even the most obvious of scripters can go a couple of weeks without actually receiving a ban.

replies.body:
> [{quoted}](name=lyD,realm=OCE,application-id=T8eq2lFQ,discussion-id=kuAnWUiA,comment-id=,timestamp=2016-03-17T08:32:56.910+0000)
> **Isn't a ban enough?**: Sure, the scripters will indeed receive a ban if they're scripting, though this takes weeks (if not months) to actually be put into action. Even the most obvious of scripters can go a couple of weeks without actually receiving a ban.

From my experience after reporting someone who was clearly scripting I will get a message saying that a player has been punished thanks to your report within a few hours

This board was more referring to the scripting problem in Oceanic rather than EUW. On Oceanic you barely ever see a message stating a scripter you've reported has been banned, and usually it's weeks (if not months) later before the ban is actually issued. 

As an example, the most obvious scripter I've seen was a TF scripter.. They were instalocking the card they wanted everytime first rotation, dodging everything to the unit (even circular skillshots before they were actually visable, such as Lux E) and cancelling AAs/stutterstepping randomly to dodge things they didn't overly need to dodge. Even scripters that obvious will go 30+ games and 1-2 weeks easily without a ban on OCE.

Edit: They do ALWAYS end up banned (longest i've seen one survive was about 3months, though they only scripted ~40-50% of their games judging by the champions they played, not all), though it's never instantly or with-in a few hours like that.

Riot don't give a fuck.
We tested this a while ago.
A friend of mine was using Katarina scripts.
I screen capped him admitting it in game, explaining it all.
Sent it all in via ticket.
I got the copypasted "We will investigate the issue but can't disclose information to you"
My friend never heard from Riot at all about it, still plays to this day.

Seriously, all Riot care about anymore is "toxicity". They want to get rid of the community's reputation as the worst in online gaming. That way new players will be more likely to continue playing, and continue to dump money into the game. All the older players are quitting because they realize how shitty the game is becoming, so they need to source their money from somewhere.

Name and shaming is a no no. (I know you didn't name and shame.)
Even tho, Yes it does suck.
There is a reason for that.
--
All you can really do, is report them for cheating after game.
And if you can, have video evidence.
But make sure they are actually scripting tho, some summoners are just good at dodging.

There is actually a way to make it more likely to see if they are scripting.
If you don't have quick cast on, and you have a skill shot (Like blitzcranks Q)
If you click Q and hover your curser over them, but dont actually click again.

You can see sudden Jagger'ed movements. (some summoners could still be predicting)
But what I mean is they will be moving pixel perfect left and right to try and avoid your hook.

When people dodge normally they often do huge strides (comparing to scripts)
While scripter's will do pixel perfect norrow dodges.

As mentioned in my post, the naming and shaming stance more seems to be mentioned when referring to calling out players for toxic behavior. I've never seen it mentioned as a general guideline or specifically when talking about calling out scripters, which is why I'm asking the question here and wanting community feedback. 

With the if they're actually scripting or not side of things, that is quite a valid point there - we don't want players going around accusing innocent enemies of scripting. However, for some a scripter is extremely easy to spot and in some situations you can be extremely sure about it. If a player is dodging everything to the exact unit and behaves the same way every time in certain situations (ie anti-gap closers, the timing is always the same) it can be extremely obvious. Another example is Twisted Fates locking the card they want AS SOON as it appears, instantly, every time with 100% accuracy - that's quite obvious.

Yeah things like this can be annoying, I dont think I have ever seen a scripter before.
But I have encountered like 1 billion freaking bots. (Which use scripts so same thing I guess)

Just video evidence and reports is all we can do as non rioters.

The bots are even worse these days, I don't believe I've had an ARAM game in the last year without at least one bot on either mine or the enemy team. Doing late night ARAMS (around 3am) results in 9 bots in a single game usually.

Yeah I actually feel like botters are more of  a problem, I cant have a game with my little brother and go Co-op VS ai (Hes like lvl 10-12) without having at least 1 to 3 bots.

I know riot bans them and all I manage to record and get a whole bunch banned which was nice.
Doesn't overly solve the problem, but build zz'rot in Co-op when your team is all/mostly bots. The enemy team (Ai) won't hit the zz'rot, meaning it guarantees you can still push, even 1v5.

Lets clear this up.

On the boards we don't allow naming and shaming, even in cases of scripting. 

As for the rest of the internet, **Riot** doesn't recommend publicly shaming scripters outside of the boards, but they can do very little to stop it. Even a copyright take down could be denied as a attempt at censorship, assuming no ad revenue was made.

Your right to free speech is what allows people to critique these scripters, and call them out for their behavior and cheating.

**Also:**

> Sure, the scripters will indeed receive a ban if they're scripting, though this takes weeks (if not months) to actually be put into action. Even the most obvious of scripters can go a couple of weeks without actually receiving a ban.

+ In most cases **Riot** can detect the program being used and issue a ban quite quickly. But in cases like the one you're referring to, the scripter has found a way to avoid **Riot**'s system. In these cases it's important that everyone reports the offending players, so that they can gather enough evidence to pass judgement.

 Please understand** Riot** needs to be 100% the person is scripting when they enforce a ban. To avoid any mistakes they can sometimes take longer than expected.

In the cases I'm referring to, the players were outright scripting carelessly without any kind of humanizer and remained unbanned for 2-3 weeks. I understand SOME may be banned more instantly, though extremely obvious scripters remaining unbanned for so long isn't a good thing.

In the particular case I refer to, the player was dodging lux Es before they were even visible, to the unit (right on the edge). They even at one point were spamming laugh while dodging, fighting with the scripts (resulting in them stutter stepping in an extremely weird, inhuman way). They remained unbanned for about a month after this particular game. At the time I got vs them they had a match history which all looked scripted as far back as 1-2 months, totaling 2-3 months of scripting before a ban was issued.

>  Please understand** Riot** needs to be 100% the person is scripting when they enforce a ban. To avoid any mistakes they can sometimes take longer than expected.

I understand, though isn't 2-3 months a little too long?


For the sake of making this easier for me to explain I'll link a video here of the particular game. I don't consider it calling the player out as I don't mention any details about him/her and they have since been banned anyway - it won't reflect back on anyone.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQ5gBMR-U5I

Edit: Note that this is barely even 1/4th of the times they dodged lux's E to the unit. Lux's E is an extremely obvious thing to prove a player's scripting as (in most cases) they'll dodge it to the single unit before it's even visible, something which is literally humanly impossible.

Yeah, they usually mark accounts for ban and ban them all at once in waves. The down side of this is we have to put up with these scripting players for another few weeks (or even months) before they're actually issued a ban. To make it worse, once banned they simply buy another account and continue doing the same thing - an account a month is nothing, $20/mo at most. The ban waves are too spread out to combat the main problem of scripters having access to unlimited accounts.
